prompt: CPT 76604, 32561. Dx: Non-Draining Pleural Effusion. 85 F. US findings: Right complex, Left simple. Rx: 10 mg tPA / 5 mg DNase to Right. Outcome: 850cc drainage.
completion:
NOTE_ID: note_019 SOURCE_FILE: note_019.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT 

DATE OF PROCEDURE: 2/7/26


INDICATION FOR OPERATION: The patient is a 85-year-old female who presents with a non-draining pleural effusion.
CONSENT Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

Non-Draining Pleural Effusion 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

Non-Draining Pleural Effusion 

PROCEDURE

Ultrasound, chest (includes mediastinum), real time with image documentation (CPT 76604)

Instillation(s), via chest tube/catheter, agent for fibrinolysis;
initial day (CPT 32561)

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After induction of anesthesia (local), a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Focused Thoracic Ultrasound Focused thoracic ultrasound was performed and relevant procedural images were saved to the medical record.
Left Hemithorax:

Pleural Effusion: No significant effusion identified.

Diaphragm: Normal motion.

Lung/Pleura: Lung sliding present pre- and post-procedure.
No consolidation/atelectasis. Pleura appears normal.

Right Hemithorax:

Pleural Effusion: Moderate volume, complex septated fluid.

Diaphragm: Elevated hemidiaphragm with poor excursion.
Lung/Pleura: Pleura appears thick.

Intrapleural Fibrinolysis (Right) The existing right-sided chest tube (inserted 2/7/26) was identified.
Agent Instilled: 10 mg tPA / 5 mg DNase (Dose #1).
Dwell Time: The agents were allowed to dwell for 45 minutes.
Drainage: Following the dwell time, drainage was performed using a wall suction.

Output: 850 cc of turbid fluid was drained.
COMPLICATIONS No immediate complications occurred. 

IMPRESSION / PLAN

Successful chest ultrasound and instillation of fibrinolytic agents for non-draining pleural effusion.
Patient tolerated the procedure well. 

Disposition: Return to ward.


Follow-up: Return to pleural clinic in 2 weeks for repeat lytics.

prompt:
Patient: 71 F
Diagnosis: complicated effusion
Procedure: US Chest + Lytics Instillation
Findings: Left (complex fluid), Right (Normal)
Action: 10 mg tPA / 5 mg DNase via Left tube
Output: 400cc bloody

Instillation(s), via chest tube/catheter, agent for fibrinolysis;
initial day (CPT 32561)

Left Hemithorax:

Pleural Effusion: Moderate volume, complex septated fluid.

Lung/Pleura: Lung sliding present pre- and post-procedure.
No consolidation/atelectasis. Pleura appears thick.

Right Hemithorax:

Pleural Effusion: Small simple effusion, free flowing.

NOTE_ID: note_019 SOURCE_FILE: note_019.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT 

DATE OF PROCEDURE: 2/13/26


INDICATION FOR OPERATION: The patient is a 94-year-old male who presents with a complex parapneumonic effusion.
CONSENT Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

Complex Parapneumonic Effusion 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

Complex Parapneumonic Effusion 

PROCEDURE

Ultrasound, chest (includes mediastinum), real time with image documentation (CPT 76604)

Instillation(s), via chest tube/catheter, agent for fibrinolysis;
initial day (CPT 32561)

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After induction of anesthesia (local), a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Focused Thoracic Ultrasound Focused thoracic ultrasound was performed and relevant procedural images were saved to the medical record.
Left Hemithorax:

Pleural Effusion: Minimal volume, anechoic echogenicity, no loculations.

Diaphragm: Normal motion.

Lung/Pleura: Lung sliding present pre- and post-procedure.
No consolidation/atelectasis. Pleura appears normal.

Right Hemithorax:

Pleural Effusion: Large volume, swirling debris, multiple loculations.

Diaphragm: Paradoxical motion.
Lung/Pleura: Diffusely thickened pleura.

Intrapleural Fibrinolysis (Right) The existing right-sided chest tube (inserted 2/13/26) was identified.
Agent Instilled: 10 mg tPA / 10 mg DNase (Dose #1).
Dwell Time: The agents were allowed to dwell for 45 minutes.
Drainage: Following the dwell time, drainage was performed using a gravity drainage.

Output: 450 cc of dark yellow fluid was drained.
COMPLICATIONS No immediate complications occurred. 

IMPRESSION / PLAN

Successful chest ultrasound and instillation of fibrinolytic agents for complex parapneumonic effusion.
Patient tolerated the procedure well. 

Disposition: Discharge home.


Follow-up: Return to pleural clinic in 10-14 days for repeat lytics.

prompt: Please write an IP op report for a 87 year old female with a loculated pleural effusion. We performed a thoracic ultrasound and fibrinolytic instillation. The ultrasound showed a loculated effusion on the Right and minimal findings on the Left. We instilled 10 mg tPA / 5 mg DNase into the Right tube. After 45 minutes, we drained 250 cc of bloody fluid.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

Complicated Effusion 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

Complicated Effusion 

PROCEDURE

Ultrasound, chest (includes mediastinum), real time with image documentation (CPT 76604)

Instillation(s), via chest tube/catheter, agent for fibrinolysis;
initial day (CPT 32561)

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After induction of anesthesia (local), a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Focused Thoracic Ultrasound Focused thoracic ultrasound was performed and relevant procedural images were saved to the medical record.
Left Hemithorax:

Pleural Effusion: Small simple effusion, free flowing.

Diaphragm: Normal motion.

Lung/Pleura: Lung sliding present pre- and post-procedure.
No consolidation/atelectasis. Pleura appears normal.

Right Hemithorax:

Pleural Effusion: Significant volume, hyperechoic strands, loculated.

Diaphragm: Elevated hemidiaphragm with poor excursion.
Lung/Pleura: Nodular pleural thickening.

Intrapleural Fibrinolysis (Right) The existing right-sided chest tube (inserted 2/14/26) was identified.
Agent Instilled: 10 mg tPA / 5 mg DNase (Dose #1).
Dwell Time: The agents were allowed to dwell for 45 minutes.
Drainage: Following the dwell time, drainage was performed using a wall suction.

Output: 550 cc of hemorrhagic fluid was drained.
COMPLICATIONS No immediate complications occurred. 

IMPRESSION / PLAN

Successful chest ultrasound and instillation of fibrinolytic agents for complicated effusion.
Patient tolerated the procedure well. 

Disposition: Remain in observation unit.


Follow-up: Return to pleural clinic in 10-14 days for repeat lytics.
